'''Aerobic fermentation''' is a metabolic process by which cells metabolize sugars via fermentation in the presence of oxygen and occurs through the repression of normal respiratory metabolism (also referred to as the [[crabtree effect]] in yeast).<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=De Deken|first=R. H.|date=1966|title=The Crabtree Effect: A Regulatory System in Yeast|url=|journal=J. Gen. Microbiol.|volume=44|pages=149–156|doi=10.1099/00221287-44-2-149|pmid=5969497}}</ref> This phenomenon is fairly rare and is primarily observed in yeasts.<ref name=":15">{{Cite journal|last=Piškur|first=Jure|last2=Rozpędowska|first2=Elżbieta|last3=Polakova|first3=Silvia|last4=Merico|first4=Annamaria|last5=Compagno|first5=Concetta|date=2006-04-01|title=How did Saccharomyces evolve to become a good brewer?|url=http://www.cell.com/article/S0168952506000333/abstract|journal=Trends in Genetics|language=English|volume=22|issue=4|pages=183–186|doi=10.1016/j.tig.2006.02.002|issn=0168-9525|pmid=16499989}}</ref> Aerobic fermentation evolved independently in at least three yeast lineages (''[[Saccharomyces]]'', ''[[Dekkera]]'', ''[[Schizosaccharomyces]]'').<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Dashko|first=Sofia|last2=Zhou|first2=Nerve|last3=Compagno|first3=Concetta|last4=Piškur|first4=Jure|date=2014-09-01|title=Why, when, and how did yeast evolve alcoholic fermentation?|url=http://femsyr.oxfordjournals.org/content/14/6/826|journal=FEMS Yeast Research|language=en|volume=14|issue=6|pages=826–832|doi=10.1111/1567-1364.12161|issn=1567-1364|pmc=4262006|pmid=24824836}}</ref> It has also been observed in plant pollen,<ref name=":2" /> trypanosomatids,<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Cazzulo|first=Juan José|date=1992|title=Aerobic fermentation of glucose by trypanosomatids|url=|journal=FASEB|doi=|pmid=1397837|volume=6|pages=3153–61}}</ref> mutated ''E. coli'',<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Portnoy|first=Vasiliy A.|last2=Herrgård|first2=Markus J.|last3=Palsson|first3=Bernhard Ø.|date=2008|title=Aerobic Fermentation of D-Glucose by an Evolved Cytochrome Oxidase-Deficient Escherichia coli Strain|journal=Appl. Environ. Microbiol.|volume=74|pages=7561–7569|doi=10.1128/AEM.00880-08|pmid=18952873|pmc=2607145}}</ref> and tumor cells.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Alfarouk|first=Khalid O.|last2=Verduzco|first2=Daniel|last3=Rauch|first3=Cyril|last4=Muddathir|first4=Abdel Khalig|last5=Adil|first5=H. H. Bashir|last6=Elhassan|first6=Gamal O.|last7=Ibrahim|first7=Muntaser E.|last8=David Polo Orozco|first8=Julian|last9=Cardone|first9=Rosa Angela|date=2014-01-01|title=Glycolysis, tumor metabolism, cancer growth and dissemination. A new pH-based etiopathogenic perspective and therapeutic approach to an old cancer question|journal=Oncoscience|volume=1|issue=12|pages=777–802|issn=2331-4737|pmc=4303887|pmid=25621294|doi=10.18632/oncoscience.109}}</ref> Crabtree-positive yeasts will respire when grown with very low concentrations of glucose or when grown on most other carbohydrate sources.<ref name=":0" /> The Crabtree effect is a regulatory system whereby respiration is repressed by fermentation, except in low sugar conditions.<ref name=":0" /> When ''[[Saccharomyces cerevisiae]]'' is grown below the sugar threshold and undergoes a respiration metabolism, the fermentation pathway is still fully expressed,<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Hagman|first=Arne|last2=Säll|first2=Torbjörn|last3=Compagno|first3=Concetta|last4=Piskur|first4=Jure|title=Yeast "Make-Accumulate-Consume" Life Strategy Evolved as a Multi-Step Process That Predates the Whole Genome Duplication|url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0068734|journal=PLoS ONE|volume=8|issue=7|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0068734|pmc=3711898|pmid=23869229|pages=e68734|bibcode=2013PLoSO...868734H}}</ref> while the respiration pathway is only expressed relative to the sugar availability.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Baumann|first=Kristin|last2=Carnicer|first2=Marc|last3=Dragosits|first3=Martin|last4=Graf|first4=Alexandra B|last5=Stadlmann|first5=Johannes|last6=Jouhten|first6=Paula|last7=Maaheimo|first7=Hannu|last8=Gasser|first8=Brigitte|last9=Albiol|first9=Joan|date=2010-10-22|title=A multi-level study of recombinant Pichia pastoris in different oxygen conditions|url=http://www.biomedcentral.com/1752-0509/4/141|journal=BMC Systems Biology|language=En|volume=4|issue=1|doi=10.1186/1752-0509-4-141|pmc=2987880|pmid=20969759|pages=141}}</ref> This contrasts with the [[pasteur effect]], which is the inhibition of fermentation in the presence of oxygen, and observed in most organisms.<ref name=":1" />
The evolution of aerobic fermentation likely involved multiple successive molecular steps,<ref name=":1" /> which included the expansion of hexose transporter genes,<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Lin|first=Zhenguo|last2=Li|first2=Wen-Hsiung|date=2011-01-01|title=Expansion of Hexose Transporter Genes Was Associated with the Evolution of Aerobic Fermentation in Evolution|language=en|volume=28|issue=1|pages=131–142|doi=10.1093/molbev/msq184|issn=0737-4038|pmc=3002240|pmid=20660490}}</ref> [[Copy-number variation|copy number variation]] (CNV)<ref yeast|url=http://msb.embopress.org/cgi/doi/10.1038/msb4100170|journal=Molecular Systems Biology|language=en|volume=3|doi=10.1038/msb4100170|pmc=1943425|pmid=17667951}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Thomson|first=J Michael|last2=Gaucher|first2=Eric A|last3=Burgan|first3=Michelle F|last4=Kee|first4=Danny W De|last5=Li|first5=Tang|last6=Aris|first6=John P|last7=Benner|first7=Steven Genetics|volume=37|issue=6|pages=630–635|doi=10.1038/ng1553|pmc=3618678|pmid=15864308}}</ref> and differential expression in metabolic genes, and regulatory reprogramming.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Lin|first=Zhenguo|last2=Li|first2=Wen-Hsiung|date=2011-04-01|title=The Evolution of Aerobic Fermentation in Schizosaccharomyces pombe Was Associated with Regulatory Reprogramming but not Nucleosome Reorganization|url=http://mbe.oxfordjournals.org/content/28/4/1407|journal=Molecular Biology and Evolution|language=en|volume=28|issue=4|pages=1407–1413|doi=10.1093/molbev/msq324|issn=0737-4038|pmc=3058771|pmid=21127171}}</ref> Research is still needed to fully understand the genomic basis of this complex phenomenon. Many crabtree-positive yeast species are used for their fermentation ability in industrial processes in the production of wine, beer, sake, bread, and bioethanol.<ref name=":17"/> Through [[domestication]], these yeast species have evolved, often through [[artificial selection]], to better fit their environment.<ref name=":17"/> Strains evolved through mechanisms that include interspecific [[Hybrid (biology)|hybridization]],<ref name=":17">{{Cite journal|last=Libkind|first=Diego|last2=Hittinger|first2=Chris Todd|last3=Valério|first3=Elisabete|last4=Gonçalves|first4=Carla|last5=Dover|first5=Jim|last6=Johnston|first6=Mark|last7=Gonçalves|first7=Paula|last8=Sampaio|first8=José Paulo|date=2011-08-30|title=Microbe domestication and the identification of the wild genetic stock of lager-brewing yeast|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/108/35/14539|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|language=en|volume=108|issue=35|pages=14539–14544|doi=10.1073/pnas.1105430108|issn=0027-8424|pmc=3167505|pmid=21873232|bibcode=2011PNAS..10814539L}}</ref> [[horizontal gene transfer]] (HGT), [[gene duplication]], pseudogenization, and gene loss.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Gibbons|first=John G|last2=Rinker|first2=David C|title=The genomics of microbial domestication in the fermented food environment|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0959437X15000787|journal=Current Opinion in Genetics & Development|volume=35|pages=1–8|doi=10.1016/j.gde.2015.07.003|pmc=4695309|pmid=26338497}}</ref>
== Origin of Crabtree effect in yeast == Approximately 100 million years ago (mya), within the yeast lineage there was a [[whole genome duplication]] (WGD).<ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Wolfe|first=Kenneth H.|title=Origin of the Yeast Whole-Genome Duplication|url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pbio.1002221|journal=PLOS Biology|volume=13|issue=8|doi=10.1371/journal.pbio.1002221|pmc=4529243|pmid=26252643|pages=e1002221}}</ref> A majority of Crabtree-positive yeasts are post-WGD yeasts.<ref name=":3" /> It was believed that the WGD was a mechanism for the development of Crabtree effect in these species due to the duplication of [[alcohol dehydrogenase]] (ADH) encoding genes and hexose transporters.<ref name=":15" /> However, recent evidence has shown that aerobic fermentation originated before the WGD and evolved as a multi-step process, potentially aided by the WGD.<ref name=":15" /> The origin of aerobic fermentation, or the first step, in ''Saccharomyces'' crabtree-positive yeasts likely occurred in the interval between the ability to grow under anaerobic conditions, horizontal transfer of anaerobic DHODase (encoded by URA1 with bacteria), and the loss of respiratory chain Complex I.<ref name=":1" /> A more pronounced Crabtree effect, the second step, likely occurred near the time of the WGD event.<ref name=":1" /> Later evolutionary events that aided in the evolution of aerobic fermentation are better understood and outlined in the Genomic basis of the crabtree effect section.
=== Driving forces === It is believed that a major driving force in the origin of aerobic fermentation was its simultaneous origin with modern fruit (~125 mya).<ref name=":15" /> These fruit provided an abundance of simple sugar food source for microbial communities, including both yeast and bacteria.<ref name=":15" /> Bacteria, at that time, were able to produce biomass at a faster rate than the yeast.<ref name=":15" /> Producing a toxic compound, like ethanol, can slow the growth of bacteria, allowing the yeast to be more competitive.<ref name=":15" /> However, the yeast still had to use a portion of the sugar it consumes to produce ethanol.<ref name=":15" /> Crabtree-positive yeasts also have increased glycolytic flow, or increased uptake of glucose and conversion to pyruvate, which compensates for using a portion of the glucose to produce ethanol rather than biomass.<ref name=":1" /> Therefore, it is believed that the original driving force was to kill competitors.<ref name=":3" /> This is supported by research that determined the kinetic behavior of the ancestral ADH protein, which was found to be optimized to make ethanol, rather than consume it.<ref name=":4" />
Further evolutionary events in the development of aerobic fermentation likely increased the efficiency of this lifestyle, including increased tolerance to ethanol and the repression of the respiratory pathway.<ref name=":3" /> In high sugar environments, ''S. cerevisiae'' outcompetes and dominants all other yeast species, except its closest relative ''[[Saccharomyces paradoxus]]''.<ref name=":16" /> The ability of ''S. cerevisiae'' to dominate in high sugar environments evolved more recently than aerobic fermentation and is dependent on the type of high-sugar environment.<ref name=":16" /> Other yeasts' growth is dependent on the pH and nutrients of the high-sugar environment.<ref name=":16">{{Cite journal|last=Williams|first=Kathryn M.|last2=Liu|first2=Ping|last3=Fay|first3=Justin C.|date=2015-08-01|title=Evolution of ecological dominance of yeast species in high-sugar environments|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/evo.12707/abstract|journal=Evolution|language=en|volume=69|issue=8|pages=2079–2093|doi=10.1111/evo.12707|issn=1558-5646|pmc=4751874|pmid=26087012}}</ref>
== Genomic basis of the crabtree effect == The genomic basis of the crabtree effect is still being investigated, and its evolution likely involved multiple successive molecular steps that increased the efficiency of the lifestyle.
=== Expansion of hexose transporter genes === [[Glucose transporter|Hexose transporters]] (HXT) are a group of proteins that are largely responsible for the uptake of glucose in yeast. In ''S. cerevisiae'', 20 ''HXT'' genes have been identified and 17 encode for glucose transporters (''HXT1-HXT17''), ''GAL2'' encodes for a galactose transporter, and ''SNF3'' and ''RGT2'' encode for glucose sensors.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Boles|first=E.|last2=Hollenberg|first2=C. P.|date=1997-08-01|title=The molecular genetics of hexose transport in yeasts|journal=FEMS Microbiology Reviews|volume=21|issue=1|pages=85–111|issn=0168-6445|pmid=9299703|doi=10.1111/j.1574-6976.1997.tb00346.x}}</ref> The number of glucose sensor genes have remained mostly consistent through the budding yeast lineage, however glucose sensors are absent from ''[[Schizosaccharomyces pombe]]''. ''Sch. pombe'' is a Crabtree-positive yeast, which developed aerobic fermentation independently from ''Saccharomyces'' lineage, and detects glucose via the cAMP-signaling pathway.<ref name=":14" /> The number of transporter genes vary significantly between yeast species and has continually increased during the evolution of the ''S. cerevisiae'' lineage. Most of the transporter genes have been generated by tandem duplication, rather than from the WGD. ''Sch. pombe'' also has a high number of transporter genes compared to its close relatives.<ref name=":9" /> Glucose uptake is believed to be a major rate-limiting step in glycolysis and replacing ''S. cerevisiae''<nowiki/>'s ''HXT1-17'' genes with a single chimera ''HXT'' gene results in decreased ethanol production or fully respiratory metabolism.<ref name=":10" /> Thus, having an efficient glucose uptake system appears to be essential to ability of aerobic fermentation.<ref name=":14" /> There is a significant positive correlation between the number of hexose transporter genes and the efficiency of ethanol production.<ref name=":9" />
=== CNV in glycolysis genes === [[File:Ethanol Fermentation english.png|thumb|A scheme of transformation of glucose to alcohol by alcoholic fermentation.]] After a WGD, one of the duplicated gene pair is often lost through fractionation; less than 10% of WGD gene pairs have remained in ''S. cerevisiae'' genome.<ref name=":10" /> A little over half of WGD gene pairs in the [[glycolysis]] reaction pathway were retained in post-WGD species, significantly higher than the overall retention rate.<ref name=":10" /> This has been associated with an increased ability to metabolize glucose into pyruvate, or higher rate of glycolysis.<ref name=":13" /> After glycolysis, pyruvate can either be further broken down by [[pyruvate decarboxylase]] (Pdc) or [[pyruvate dehydrogenase]] (Pdh). The kinetics of the enzymes are such that when pyruvate concentrations are high, due to a high rate of glycolysis, there is increased flux through Pdc and thus the fermentation pathway.<ref name=":10" /> The WGD is believed to have played a beneficial role in the evolution of the Crabtree effect in post-WGD species partially due to this increase in copy number of glycolysis genes.<ref name=":14" />
=== CNV in fermentation genes === The fermentation reaction only involves two steps. Pyruvate is converted to acetaldehyde by Pdc and then acetaldehyde is converted to ethanol by [[alcohol dehydrogenase]] (Adh). There is no significant increase in the number of ''Pdc'' genes in Crabtree-positive compared to Crabtree-negative species and no correlation between number of ''Pdc'' genes and efficiency of fermentation.<ref name=":14">{{Cite book|url=https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/978-3-642-55013-3_5|title=Comparative Genomics and Evolutionary Genetics of Yeast Carbon Metabolism|last=Lin|first=Zhenguo|last2=Li|first2=Wen-Hsiung|date=2014-01-01|publisher=Springer Berlin Heidelberg|isbn=9783642550126|editor-last=Piškur|editor-first=Jure|pages=97–120|language=en|editor-last2=Compagno|editor-first2=Concetta}}</ref> There are five ''Adh'' genes in ''S. cerevisiae''.<ref name=":14" /> Adh1 is the major enzyme responsible for catalyzing the fermentation step from acetaldehyde to ethanol.<ref name=":4" /> Adh2 catalyzes the reverse reaction, consuming ethanol and converting it to acetaldehyde.<ref name=":4" /> The ancestral, or original, Adh had a similar function as Adh1 and after a duplication in this gene, Adh2 evolved a lower K<sub>M</sub> for ethanol.<ref name=":4" /> Adh2 is believed to have increased yeast species' tolerance for ethanol and allowed Crabtree-positive species to consume the ethanol they produced after depleting sugars.<ref name=":4" /> However, Adh2 and consumption of ethanol is not essential for aerobic fermentation.<ref name=":4" /> ''Sch. pombe'' and other Crabtree positive species do not have the ''ADH2'' gene and consumes ethanol very poorly.<ref name=":4" />
=== Differential expression === In Crabtree-negative species, respiration related genes are highly expressed in the presence of oxygen. However, when ''S. cerevisiae'' is grown on glucose in aerobic conditions, respiration-related gene expression is repressed. Mitochondrial ribosomal proteins expression is only induced under environmental stress conditions, specifically low glucose availability.<ref name=":14" /> Genes involving mitochondrial energy generation and phosphorylation oxidation, which are involved in respiration, have the largest expression difference between aerobic fermentative yeast species and respiratory species.<ref name=":14" /> In a comparative analysis between ''Sch. pombe'' and ''S. cerevisiae'', both of which evolved aerobic fermentation independently, the expression pattern of these two fermentative yeasts were more similar to each other than a respiratory yeast, ''C. albicans''. However, ''S. cerevisiae'' is evolutionarily closer to ''C. albicans''.<ref name=":5" /> Regulatory rewiring was likely important in the evolution of aerobic fermentation in both lineages.<ref name=":14" />
== Domestication and aerobic fermentation == [[File:Wine Grapes with dusting that contains yeast.jpg|thumb|A close up picture of ripening wine grapes. The light white "dusting" is a film that also contains wild yeasts.]] Aerobic fermentation is also essential for multiple industries, resulting in human domestication of several yeast strains. Beer and other alcoholic beverages, throughout human history, have played a significant role in society through drinking rituals, providing nutrition, medicine, and uncontaminated water.<ref name=":17" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Legras|first=Jean-Luc|last2=Merdinoglu|first2=Didier|last3=Cornuet|first3=Jean-Marie|last4=Karst|first4=Francis|date=2007-05-01|title=Bread, beer and wine: Saccharomyces cerevisiae diversity reflects human history|journal=Molecular Ecology|volume=16|issue=10|pages=2091–2102|doi=10.1111/j.1365-294X.2007.03266.x|issn=0962-1083|pmid=17498234}}</ref> During the domestication process, organisms shift from natural environments that are more variable and complex to simple and stable environments with a constant substrate. This often favors specialization adaptations in domesticated microbes, associated with relaxed selection for non-useful genes in alternative metabolic strategies or pathogenicity.<ref name=":12" /> Domestication might be partially responsible for the traits that promote aerobic fermentation in industrial species. Introgression and HGT is common in ''Saccharomyces'' domesticated strains.<ref name=":12" /> Many commercial wine strains have significant portions of their DNA derived from HGT of non-''Saccharomyces'' species. HGT and introgression are less common in nature than is seen during domestication pressures.<ref name=":12" /> For example, the important industrial yeast strain ''[[Saccharomyces pastorianus]]'', is an interspecies hybrid of ''S. cerevisiae'' and the cold tolerant ''[[Saccharomyces eubayanus|S. eubayanus]].''<ref name=":17"/> This hybrid is commonly used in lager-brewing, which requires slow, low temperature fermentation.<ref name=":17"/>
== Aerobic fermentation in non-yeast species ==
=== Plants === Alcoholic fermentation is often used by plants in anaerobic conditions to produce [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] and regenerate [[NAD+|NAD<sup>+</sup>]] to allow for glycolysis to continue. For most plant tissues, fermentation only occurs in anaerobic conditions, but there are a few exceptions. In the pollen of [[maize]] (''Zea mays'')<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tadege|first=Million|last2=Dupuis|first2=Isabelle|last3=Kuhlemeier|first3=Cris|date=1999-08-01|title=Ethanolic fermentation: new functions for an old pathway|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1360138599014508|journal=Trends in Plant Science|volume=4|issue=8|pages=320–325|doi=10.1016/S1360-1385(99)01450-8}}</ref> and [[tobacco]] (''Nicotiana tabacum'' & ''Nicotiana plumbaginifolia''), the fermentation enzyme ADH is abundant, regardless of the oxygen level. In tobacco pollen, PDC is also highly expressed in this tissue and transcript levels are not influenced by oxygen concentration. Tobacco pollen, similar to Crabtree-positive yeast, perform high levels of fermentation dependent on the sugar supply, and not oxygen availability. In these tissues, respiration and alcoholic fermentation occur simultaneously with high sugar availability.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Tadege|first=M.|last2=Kuhlemeier|first2=C.|date=1997-10-01|title=Aerobic fermentation during tobacco pollen development|journal=Plant Molecular Biology|volume=35|issue=3|pages=343–354|issn=0167-4412|pmid=9349258|doi=10.1023/A:1005837112653}}</ref> Fermentation produces the toxic acetaldehyde and ethanol, that can build up in large quantities during pollen development. It has been hypothesized that acetaldehyde is a pollen factor that causes [[cytoplasmic male sterility]]. Cytoplasmic male sterility is a trait observed in maize, tobacco and other plants in which there is an inability to produce viable pollen. It is believed that this trait might be due to the expression of the fermentation genes, ADH and PDC, a lot earlier on in pollen development than normal and the accumulation of toxic aldehyde.<ref name=":2" />
=== Trypanosomatids === When grown in glucose-rich media, [[Trypanosomatida|trypanosomatid]] parasites degrade glucose via aerobic fermentation.<ref name=":6" /> In this group, this phenomenon is not a pre-adaptation to/or remnant of anaerobic life, shown through their inability to survive in anaerobic conditions.<ref name=":18" /> It is believed that this phenomenon developed due to the capacity for a high glycolytic flux and the high glucose concentrations of their natural environment. The mechanism for repression of respiration in these conditions is not yet known.<ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=Bringaud|first=Frédéric|last2=Rivière|first2=Loïc|last3=Coustou|first3=Virginie|date=2006-09-01|title=Energy metabolism of trypanosomatids: Adaptation to available carbon sources|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0166685106001150|journal=Molecular and Biochemical Parasitology|volume=149|issue=1|pages=1–9|doi=10.1016/j.molbiopara.2006.03.017}}</ref>
=== ''E. coli'' mutant === A couple ''Escherichia coli'' mutant strains have been bioengineered to ferment glucose under aerobic conditions.<ref name=":8" /> One group developed the ECOM3 (''E. coli'' cytochrome oxidase mutant) strain by removing three terminal cytochrome oxidases (cydAB, cyoABCD, and cbdAB) to reduce oxygen uptake.<ref name=":8" /> After 60 days of adaptive evolution on glucose media, the strain displayed a mixed phenotype.<ref name=":8" /> In aerobic conditions, some populations' fermentation solely produced lactate, while others did mixed-acid fermentation.<ref name=":8" />[[File:Warburgh Effect.gif|thumb|Myc and HIF-1 regulate glucose metabolism and stimulate the Warburg effect.]]
=== Tumor cells === One of the hallmarks of cancer is altered metabolism or deregulating cellular energetics.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hanahan|first=Douglas|date=4 March 2011|title=Hallmarks of Cancer: The Next Generation|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0092867411001279|journal=Cell|doi=10.1016/j.cell.2011.02.013|pmid=21376230|access-date=|volume=144|pages=646–674}}</ref> Cancers cells often have reprogrammed their glucose metabolism to perform lactic acid fermentation, in the presence of oxygen, rather than send the pyruvate made through glycolysis to the mitochondria. This is referred to as the [[Warburg effect (oncology)|Warburg effect]], and is associated with high consumption of glucose and a high rate of glycolysis.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Warburg|first=Prof Otto|date=1925-03-01|title=über den Stoffwechsel der Carcinomzelle|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01726151|journal=Klinische Wochenschrift|language=de|volume=4|issue=12|pages=534–536|doi=10.1007/BF01726151|issn=0023-2173}}</ref> ATP production in these cancer cells is often only through the process of glycolysis and pyruvate is broken down by the fermentation process in the cell's cytoplasm. This phenomenon is often seen as counterintuitive, since cancer cells have higher energy demands due to the continued proliferation and respiration produces significantly more ATP than glycolysis alone (fermentation produces no additional ATP). Typically, there is an up-regulation in glucose transporters and enzymes in the glycolysis pathway (also seen in yeast).<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Diaz-Ruiz|first=Rodrigo|last2=Rigoulet|first2=Michel|last3=Devin|first3=Anne|title=The Warburg and Crabtree effects: On the origin of cancer cell energy metabolism and of yeast glucose repression|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0005272810006869|journal=Biochimica et Biophysica Acta (BBA) - Bioenergetics|volume=1807|issue=6|pages=568–576|doi=10.1016/j.bbabio.2010.08.010}}</ref> There are many parallel aspects of aerobic fermentation in tumor cells that are also seen in Crabtree-positive yeasts. Further research into the evolution of aerobic fermentation in yeast such as ''S. cerevisiae'' can be a useful model for understanding aerobic fermentation in tumor cells. This has a potential for better understanding cancer and cancer treatments.<ref name=":7" />

'''Bioconversion''', also known as ''biotransformation'', is the conversion of organic materials, such as plant or animal waste, into usable products or [[energy source]]s by biological processes or agents, such as certain microorganisms. One example is the industrial production of [[cortisone]], which one step is the bioconversion of [[progesterone]] to 11-alpha-Hydroxyprogesterone by ''[[Rhizopus nigricans]].'' Another example is the [[Bioconversion of Glycerol to 1,3-Propanediol|bioconversion of glycerol to 1,3-propanediol]], which is part of scientific research for many decades.
Another example of bioconversion is the [[Conversion (chemistry)|conversion]] of [[organic material]]s, such as plant or animal waste, into usable products or [[energy source]]s by biological processes or agents, such as certain [[microorganism]]s, some [[detritivore]]s or [[enzyme]]s.
In the USA, the Bioconversion Science and Technology group performs multidisciplinary R&D for the [[United_States_Department_of_Energy|Department of Energy]]'s (DOE) relevant applications of bioprocessing, especially with biomass. Bioprocessing combines the disciplines of chemical engineering, microbiology and biochemistry. The Group 's primary role is investigation of the use of microorganism, microbial consortia and microbial enzymes in bioenergy research. New [[cellulosic ethanol]] conversion processes have enabled the variety and volume of [[feedstock]] that can be bioconverted to expand rapidly. Feedstock now includes materials derived from plant or animal waste such as paper, auto-fluff, tires, fabric, construction materials, [[municipal solid waste]] (MSW), [[sludge]], [[sewage]], etc.
==Three different processes for bioconversion== 1 -''' Enzymatic hydrolysis''' - a single source of feedstock, switchgrass for example, is mixed with strong enzymes which convert a portion of cellulosic material into sugars which can then be fermented into ethanol. [[Genencor]] and [[Novozymes]] are two companies that have received United States government Department of Energy funding for research into reducing the cost of cellulase, a key enzyme in the production cellulosic ethanol by this process.
2 - '''Synthesis gas fermentation''' - a blend of feedstock, not exceeding 30% water, is [[gasified]] in a closed environment into a [[syngas]] containing mostly carbon monoxide and hydrogen. The cooled syngas is then converted into usable products through exposure to bacteria or other catalysts. BRI Energy, LLC<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brienergy.com/|title=Clean Technology for Renewable Energy|website=www.brienergy.com}}</ref> is a company whose pilot plant in Fayetteville, Arkansas is currently using synthesis gas fermentation to convert a variety of waste into ethanol. After gasification, anaerobic bacteria (''[[Clostridium ljungdahlii]]'') are used to convert the syngas ([[carbon monoxide|CO]], [[carbon dioxide|CO<sub>2</sub>]], and [[hydrogen|H<sub>2</sub>]]) into ethanol. The heat generated by gasification is also used to co-generate excess electricity.
3 - '''C.O.R.S.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Diener | first=Stefan | last2=Zurbrügg | first2=Christian | last3=Tockner | first3=Klement | title=Conversion of organic material by black soldier fly larvae: establishing optimal feeding rates | journal=Waste Management & Research | publisher=SAGE Publications | volume=27 | issue=6 | date=2009-06-05 | issn=0734-242X | doi=10.1177/0734242x09103838 | pages=603–610 | ref=harv}}</ref> and Grub Composting''' are sustainable technologies<ref>{{cite journal | last=Craig Sheppard | first=D. | last2=Larry Newton | first2=G. | last3=Thompson | first3=Sidney A. | last4=Savage | first4=Stan | title=A value added manure management system using the black soldier fly | journal=Bioresource Technology | publisher=Elsevier BV | volume=50 | issue=3 | year=1994 | issn=0960-8524 | doi=10.1016/0960-8524(94)90102-3 | pages=275–279 | ref=harv}}</ref> that employ organisms that feed on organic matter to reduce and convert organic waste in to high quality feedstuff and oil rich material for the biodiesel industry.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Li | first=Qing | last2=Zheng | first2=Longyu | last3=Cai | first3=Hao | last4=Garza | first4=E. | last5=Yu | first5=Ziniu | last6=Zhou | first6=Shengde | title=From organic waste to biodiesel: Black soldier fly, Hermetia illucens, makes it feasible | journal=Fuel | publisher=Elsevier BV | volume=90 | issue=4 | year=2011 | issn=0016-2361 | doi=10.1016/j.fuel.2010.11.016 | pages=1545–1548 | ref=harv}}</ref> Organizations pioneering this novel approach to [[waste management]] are [[EAWAG]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.eawag.ch/forschung/sandec/gruppen/swm/projects/cors/index_EN|title=Abteilung Siedlungshygiene und Wasser für Entwicklung - Eawag|website=www.eawag.ch}}</ref>, ESR International<ref>http://www.esrint.com/pages/bioconversion.html</ref>, Prota Culture<ref>http://www.thebiopod.com</ref> and BIOCONVERSION<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bioconversion.it/|title=Contatti|website=www.bioconversion.it}}</ref> that created the ''e''-CORS® system<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304054800/http://www.bioconversion.it/1/upload/bioconversion_presentazione_web.pdf|title=Wayback Machine|date=4 March 2012|publisher=}}</ref> to meet large scale organic waste management needs and environmental sustainability in both urban and livestock farming reality. This type of engineered system introduces a substantial innovation represented by the automatic modulation of the treatment, able to adapt conditions of the system to the biology of the scavenger used, improving their performances and the power of this technology.

{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} [[File:Raumaustragung Hackschnitzel.JPG|thumb|Wood chips in a storage hopper, in the middle an agitator to transport the material with a screw conveyor to the boiler]] '''Biomass heating systems''' generate heat from [[biomass]].
The systems fall under the categories of: *direct [[combustion]], *[[gasification]], *[[combined heat and power]] (CHP), *[[anaerobic digestion]], *[[aerobic digestion]]. ==Benefits of biomass heating== The use of biomass in [[heating system]]s is beneficial because it uses agricultural, forest, urban and industrial residues and waste to produce heat and electricity with less effect on the [[Natural environment|environment]] than fossil fuels.{{Cite journal | last1 = Vallios | first1 = I | last2 = Tsoutsos | first2 = T | last3 = Papadakis | first3 = G | year = 2009 | title = Design of Biomass District Heating | url = | journal = Biomass & Bioenergy | volume = 33 | issue = 4| pages = 659–678 }} This type of energy production has a limited long-term effect on the environment because the carbon in biomass is part of the natural [[carbon cycle]]; while the carbon in fossil fuels is not, and permanently adds carbon to the environment when burned for fuel ([[carbon footprint]]).{{cite web |title= Wood Fuelled Heating |url= http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/Generate-your-own-energy/Wood-fuelled-heating |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110716153317/http://www.energysavingtrust.org.uk/Generate-your-own-energy/Wood-fuelled-heating |archivedate= 16 July 2011 |df= dmy-all }} Historically, before the use of [[fossil fuels]] in significant quantities, biomass in the form of [[wood fuel]] provided most of humanity's heating. ==Drawbacks of biomass heating== On a large scale, the use of biomass removes [[agricultural land]] from [[food production]], reduces the [[carbon sequestration]] capacity of forests, and extracts [[soil nutrient|nutrients]] from the soil. Combustion of biomass creates [[air pollutant]]s and adds significant quantities of carbon to the atmosphere that may not be returned to the soil for many decades.{{cite web|url=http://www.eea.europa.eu/about-us/governance/scientific-committee/sc-opinions/opinions-on-scientific-issues/sc-opinion-on-greenhouse-gas |title=Opinion of the EEA Scientific Committee on Greenhouse Gas Accounting in Relation to Bioenergy }} Using biomass as a fuel produces air pollution in the form of [[carbon monoxide]], [[NOx]] (nitrogen oxides), VOCs ([[volatile organic compound]]s), particulates and other pollutants, in some cases at levels above those from traditional fuel sources such as coal or natural gas.{{cite web|url=http://michiganmessenger.com/33868/proposed-biomass-plant-better-than-coal |title=George Lopez visits the Fox Theatre |publisher=Michigan Messenger |date=22 February 1999 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100205080916/http://michiganmessenger.com/33868/proposed-biomass-plant-better-than-coal |archivedate=5 February 2010 |df=dmy }}{{cite journal|pmc=1892127 | pmid=17589590 | doi=10.1289/ehp.9479 | volume=115 | issue=6 | title=Household air pollution from coal and biomass fuels in China: measurements, health impacts, and interventions |date=June 2007 | journal=Environ. Health Perspect. | pages=848–55}} [[Black carbon]] – a pollutant created by incomplete combustion of fossil fuels, biofuels, and biomass – is possibly the second largest contributor to global warming.''2009 State of the World, Into a Warming World'','''Worldwatch Institute''', 56–57, {{ISBN|978-0-393-33418-0}} In 2009 a Swedish study of the giant brown haze that periodically covers large areas in South Asia determined that it had been principally produced by biomass burning, and to a lesser extent by fossil-fuel burning.''Science'', '''2009''', 323, 495 Researchers measured a significant concentration of [[Carbon-14|14C]], which is associated with recent plant life rather than with fossil fuels.''Biomass burning leads to Asian brown cloud'', [[Chemical & Engineering News]], '''87''', 4, 31 On combustion, the carbon from biomass is released into the atmosphere as [[carbon dioxide|carbon dioxide (CO2)]]. The amount of carbon stored in dry wood is approximately 50% by weight.{{cite web|url=http://www.uvm.edu/~jcjenkin/smith%20et%20al.%202003.pdf |title=Forest volume-to-biomass models and estimates of mass for live and standing dead trees of U.S. forests |format=PDF |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070711174829/http://www.uvm.edu/~jcjenkin/smith%20et%20al.%202003.pdf |archivedate=11 July 2007 |df=dmy }} When from agricultural sources, plant matter used as a fuel can be replaced by planting for new growth. When the biomass is from forests, the time to recapture the carbon stored is generally longer, and the carbon storage capacity of the forest may be reduced overall if destructive forestry techniques are employed.{{cite web|last=Prasad|first=Ram|title=SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT FOR DRY FORESTS OF SOUTH ASIA|url=http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/003/X6895E/x6895e04.htm|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|accessdate=11 August 2010}}{{cite web|title=Treetrouble: Testimonies on the Negative Impact of Large-scale Tree Plantations prepared for the sixth Conference of the Parties of the Framework Convention on Climate Change|url=http://www.foei.org/en/resources/forests/treetrouble.html|publisher=Friends of the Earth International|accessdate=11 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726122033/http://www.foei.org/en/resources/forests/treetrouble.html|archivedate=26 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|title=Impacts of intensive forestry on early rotation trends in site carbon pools in the southeastern US|url=http://www.srs.fs.usda.gov/pubs/5295|publisher=United States Department of Agriculture|accessdate=11 August 2010|author=Laiho, Raija|author2=Sanchez, Felipe |author3=Tiarks, Allan |author4=Dougherty, Phillip M. |author5= Trettin, Carl C. }}{{cite web|title=THE FINANCIAL AND INSTITUTIONAL FEASIBILITY OF SUSTAINABLE FOREST MANAGEMENT|url=http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/003/X4107E/X4107E04.htm#P866_112288|publisher=Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|accessdate=11 August 2010}} The biomass-is-carbon-neutral proposal put forward in the early 1990s has been superseded by more recent science that recognizes that mature, intact forests sequester carbon more effectively than cut-over areas. When a tree’s carbon is released into the atmosphere in a single pulse, it contributes to climate change much more than woodland timber rotting slowly over decades.{{cite web |url=http://www.massenvironmentalenergy.org/docs/MEEA%20biomass%20briefing%20August%20update.pdf |work=massenvironmentalenergy.org |title=Biomass Briefing, October 2009 |publisher=Massachusetts Environmental Energy Alliance |author=Mary S. Booth |accessdate=12 December 2010 }} Current studies indicate that "even after 50 years the forest has not recovered to its initial carbon storage" and "the optimal strategy is likely to be protection of the standing forest".Edmunds, Joe; Richard Richets; Marshall Wise, "Future Fossil Fuel Carbon Emissions without Policy Intervention: A Review". In T. M. L. Wigley, David Steven Schimel, ''The carbon cycle''. Cambridge University Press, 2000, pp.171–189 ==Biomass heating in our world== [[File:Olarizu - Casa de la Dehesa - Central de biomasa 01.jpg|thumb|Biomass heating system for one building complex in the Spanish Basque Country]] The [[oil price increases since 2003]] and consequent price increases for natural gas and coal have increased the value of biomass for heat generation. Forest renderings, agricultural waste, and [[energy crop|crops grown specifically for energy]] production become competitive as the prices of [[Energy density|energy dense]] fossil fuels rise. Efforts to develop this potential may have the effect of [[Land reclamation#Repairing damaged land|regenerating mismanaged croplands]] and be a cog in the wheel of a decentralized, multi-dimensional [[renewable energy industry]]. Efforts to promote and advance these methods became common throughout the [[European Union]] through the 2000s. In other areas of the world, inefficient and polluting means to generate heat from biomass coupled with poor forest practices have significantly added to [[environmental degradation]]. ==Buffer tanks== Buffer tanks store the hot water the biomass appliance generates and circulates it around the heating system.{{Cite web|url=http://www.treco.co.uk/products/type/buffertank/2|title=Buffer Tanks and Hot Water Storage - Treco|website=www.treco.co.uk|access-date=2016-10-18}} Sometimes referred to as 'thermal stores', they are crucial for the efficient operation of all biomass boilers where the system loading fluctuates rapidly, or the volume of water in the complete hydraulic system is relatively small. Using a suitably sized buffer vessel prevents rapid cycling of the boiler when the loading is below the minimum boiler output. Rapid cycling of the boiler causes a large increase in harmful emissions such as [[Carbon monoxide]], dust, and [[NOx]], greatly reduces boiler efficiency and increases electrical consumption of the unit. In addition, service and maintenance requirements will be increased as parts are stressed by rapid heating and cooling cycles. Although most boilers claim to be able to turn down to 30% of nominal output, in the real world this is often not achievable due to differences in the fuel from the 'ideal' or test fuel. A suitably sized buffer tank should therefore be considered where the loading of the boiler drops below 50% of the nominal output – in other words unless the biomass component is purely base load, the system should include a buffer tank. In any case where the secondary system does not contain sufficient water for safe removal of residual heat from the biomass boiler irrespective of the loading conditions, the system must include a suitably sized buffer tank. The [[residual heat]] from a biomass unit varies greatly depending on the boiler design and the thermal mass of the combustion chamber. Light weight, fast response boilers require only 10L/kW, while industrial wet wood units with very high thermal mass require 40L/kW.{{cite web |title=Buffer tanks |url= http://www.mbaxterbiomass.co.uk/services/buffer.html }} ==Types of biomass heating systems== [[File:Biomasseheizwerk Spillern Nordansicht.jpg|thumb|Biomass [[Heat-only boiler station|heating plant]] in Austria; the heat power is about 1000 kW]] The use of Biomass in heating systems has a use in many different types of buildings, and all have different uses. There are four main types of heating systems that use biomass to heat a boiler. The types are Fully Automated, Semi-Automated, Pellet-Fired, and Combined Heat and Power. ===Fully automated=== In fully automated systems chipped or ground up waste wood is brought to the site by delivery trucks and dropped into a holding tank. A system of conveyors then transports the wood from the holding tank to the boiler at a certain managed rate. This rate is managed by computer controls and a laser that measures the load of fuel the conveyor is bringing in. The system automatically goes on and off to maintain the pressure and temperature within the boiler. Fully automated systems offer a great deal of ease in their operation because they only require the operator of the system to control the computer, and not the transport of wood while offering comprehensive and cost effective solutions to complex industrial challenges.{{Cite news|url=http://www.sigmathermal.com/automation|title=Automation: Combustion Control & Burner Management Systems|newspaper=Sigma Thermal|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-18}}{{cite web |title=Types of Biomass Heating Systems |url= http://www.hurstboiler.com/biomass_boiler_systems/heating_system_types/ }} ===Semi-automated or "surge bin"=== Semi-automated or "Surge Bin" systems are very similar to fully automated systems except they require more manpower to keep operational. They have smaller holding tanks, and a much simpler conveyor systems which will require personnel to maintain the systems operation. The reasoning for the changes from the fully automated system is the efficiency of the system. The heat created by the combustor can be used to directly heat the air or it can be used to heat water in a boiler system which acts as the medium by which the heat is delivered.{{Cite news|url=http://selectedecoenergy.co.uk/biomass-system-design/|title=Biomass System Design - Selected Eco Energy|newspaper=Selected Eco Energy|language=en-US|access-date=2016-10-18}} Wood fire fueled boilers are most efficient when they are running at their highest capacity, and the heat required most days of the year will not be the peak heat requirement for the year. Considering that the system will only need to run at a high capacity a few days of the year, it is made to meet the requirements for the majority of the year to maintain its high efficiency. ===Pellet-fired=== The third main type of biomass heating systems are [[Pellet fuel|pellet]]-fired systems. Pellets are a processed form of wood, which make them more expensive. Although they are more expensive, they are much more condensed and uniform, and therefore are more efficient. Further, it is relatively easy to automatically feed pellets to boilers. In these systems, the pellets are stored in a grain-type storage silo, and gravity is used to move them to the boiler. The storage requirements are much smaller for pellet-fired systems because of their condensed nature, which also helps cut down costs. these systems are used for a wide variety of facilities, but they are most efficient and cost effective for places where space for storage and conveyor systems is limited, and where the pellets are made fairly close to the facility. ====Agricultural pellet systems==== One subcategory of pellet systems are boilers or burners capable of burning pellet with higher ash rate (paper pellets, hay pellets, [[straw pellets]]). One of this kind is PETROJET pellet burner with rotating cylindrical burning chamber.{{cite web|url=http://www.horakypetrojet.cz/news/great-results-from-swedish-testing-laboratory |title=Great results from Swedish testing laboratory | Petrojet Trade s.r.o |publisher=Horakypetrojet.cz }} In terms of efficiencies advanced pellet boilers can exceed other forms of biomass because of the more stable fuel charataristics. Advanced pellet boilers can even work in condensing mode and cool down combustion gases to 30-40 °C, instead of 120 °C before sent into the flue.{{cite web|url=http://www.okofen.co.uk/en/pellematic_plus/#tab2|title=Okofen condesing pellet boiler}} ===Combined heat and power=== [[Combined heat and power]] systems are very useful systems in which wood waste, such as [[wood chips]], is used to generate power, and heat is created as a byproduct of the power generation system. They have a very high cost because of the high pressure operation. Because of this high pressure operation, the need for a highly trained operator is mandatory, and will raise the cost of operation. Another drawback is that while they produce electricity they will produce heat, and if producing heat is not desirable for certain parts of the year, the addition of a cooling tower is necessary, and will also raise the cost. There are certain situations where CHP is a good option. Wood product manufacturers would use a combined heat and power system because they have a large supply of waste wood, and a need for both heat and power. Other places where these systems would be optimal are hospitals and prisons, which need energy, and heat for hot water. These systems are sized so that they will produce enough heat to match the average heat load so that no additional heat is needed, and a cooling tower is not needed. ==See also== *[[Wood fuel]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.biomassthermal.org Biomass Thermal Energy Council – Information on Biomass and legislation on biomass in the US] *[http://www.pebble-heater.com/PowerGen-Article.pdf Innovative biomass power plant based on pebble-heater technology and hot air turbine] {{Bioenergy}} {{Sustainability}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Biomass Heating System}} [[Category:Bioenergy]] [[Category:Waste management concepts]] [[Category:Sustainable forest management]] [[Category:Biomass]]

A '''book desert''' is a geographic area (country, state, county, city, neighborhood, home) where printed books and other reading material are allegedly hard to obtain, particularly without access to an automobile or other form of transportation.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Neuman|first=Susan B.|last2=Moland|first2=Naomi|date=2016-07-05|title=Book Deserts The Consequences of Income Segregation on Children's Access to Print|url=http://uex.sagepub.com/content/early/2016/07/05/0042085916654525|journal=Urban Education|language=en|pages=0042085916654525|doi=10.1177/0042085916654525|issn=0042-0859}}</ref> Some researchers have defined book deserts by linking them to poverty and low income, while others use a combination of factors that include census data, income, ethnicity, geography, language, and the number of books in a home.<ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.greeleytribune.com/news/12397504-113/book-books-literacy-desert#|title=Searching for oases in Weld's so-called book desert|last=Silvy|first=Tyler|date=July 30, 2014|work=Greeley Tribune|access-date=August 6, 2016|via=}}</ref>
Initiatives that increase the availability of books by such measures as [[bookmobiles]] and librarians on bicycles have been offered as possible solutions to book deserts, as have [[Little Free Library|Little Free Libraries]] and offering children's literature available online, free of charge.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ur9ep9bn4s.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fsummon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=Literacy+initiative+aims+to+eliminate+%27book+deserts%27&rft.jtitle=Dayton+Daily+News&rft.au=ByJeff+Gilbert&rft.date=2016-06-26&rft.pub=CMG+Corporate+Services%2C+Inc.+on+behalf+of+itself+and+the+Newspapers&rft.issn=0897-0920&rft.externalDocID=4100425741&paramdict=en-US|title=Literacy initiative aims to eliminate 'book deserts'|last=Gilbert|first=Jeff|date=June 26, 2016|work=Dayton Daily News|subscription=yes|access-date=August 6, 2016|via=}}</ref>
== Background and research == In the past, researchers have studied how the absence or scarcity of books impact how a child's early [[literacy]] and language skills develop.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Evans|first=M. D. R.|last2=Kelley|first2=Jonathan|last3=Sikora|first3=Joanna|last4=Treiman|first4=Donald J.|date=2010-06-01|title=Family scholarly culture and educational success: Books and schooling in 27 nations|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0276562410000090|journal=Research in Social Stratification and Mobility|volume=28|issue=2|pages=171–197|doi=10.1016/j.rssm.2010.01.002}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.literacytrust.org.uk/blog/2196_a_book_of_their_own_how_owning_books_affects_childrens_literacy|title=A book of their own: how owning books affects children's literacy|last=Poulton|first=Lizzie|date=July 7, 2010|website=Literacy Trust|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-06}}</ref> The term "book desert" came into regular use in the mid-2010s and the [[social enterprise]] [http://www.uniteforliteracy.com Unite for Literacy] is credited as having coined the term.<ref name=":1" /> Unite for Literacy created an operational definition of a book desert when they published the U.S. Book Desert Map: A geographic area (country, state, county, census tract) where it is predicted that a majority of homes have less than 100 printed books. In March 2014, James LaRue, director of the [[American Library Association]]'s Office for [[Intellectual Freedom]] and the [[Freedom to Read Foundation]], used the term in an issue of ''[[American Libraries]]'', where he described the term as applying to houses with 25 or fewer books in them and discussed ways to lessen or eradicate the problem.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://americanlibrariesmagazine.org/blogs/e-content/the-price-is-right-at-unite-for-literacy/|title=The Price Is Right at Unite for Literacy|last=LaRue|first=James|date=March 4, 2014|website=American Libraries Magazine|access-date=2016-08-06}}</ref>
In July 2016, professors [[Susan B. Neuman]] and Naomi Moland published a study in ''[[Urban Education]]'', where they examined how the lack of printed reading material among low-income and poverty stricken neighborhoods impacts early childhood development and used the term to describe areas and homes with little access to written materials.<ref name=":0" /> This study built upon other research Neuman had conducted in 2001 on the same topic and the researchers found few stores in [[Detroit]], [[Los Angeles]], and [[Washington, D.C.]]; the focus areas of their research had print resources for children ages 0 through 18.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/education/archive/2016/07/where-books-are-nonexistent/491282/|title=The Children Who Grow Up in 'Book Deserts'|last=Wong|first=Alia|date=July 14, 2016|website=The Atlantic|publisher=|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-06}}</ref> Of those stores, many were [[dollar stores]].<ref name=":2" /> ''The Atlantic'' reported that in 2015 Neuman and [[JetBlue|JetBlue Airways]] held an experiment to foster literacy by providing book vending machines in a low-income Washington D.C. neighborhood. Over 20,000 books were given away, prompting Neuman to conclude that the neighborhood's parents did care about their children's education but lacked "the resources to enable their children to be successful."<ref name=":2" />
=== Contributing factors === Multiple factors are credited as contributing to the formation of book deserts, the most frequently highlighted of which tends to be poverty and low income. Other factors tend to include language and geography, as some areas lack access to bookstores or public or community school libraries that would provide books.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://wkbn.com/2016/07/29/warren-group-works-to-fight-book-desert-phenomenon/|title=Warren group works to fight 'book desert' phenomenon|last=Santelli|first=James|date=July 30, 2016|website=WKBN|publisher=|access-date=2016-08-06}}</ref> [[Bookselling|Book store]] closures due to [[bankruptcy]] or other financial difficulties are also occasionally cited as a contributing factor, when the closure leaves the area without a bookseller.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://go.galegroup.com.ezproxy2.library.drexel.edu/ps/i.do?p=AONE&u=drexel_main&id=GALE|A286307818&v=2.1&it=r&sid=summon&userGroup=drexel_main&authCount=1|title=Store closures create US 'book deserts'|last=Gelles|first=David|date=April 14, 2012|work=The Financial Times|subscription=yes|access-date=August 6, 2016|via=Academic OneFile}}</ref>
== Depictions == [[File:Unite Book Desert Map.jpg|thumb|US Book Desert map from Unite for Literacy]]
Unite for Literacy has developed a book desert map of the [[United States]] powered by [[Esri]]'s ArcGIS platform, which provides a visual presentation of the lack of books in the nation, states, counties and [[census tract]]s.<ref>http://www.uniteforliteracy.com/corp/esri</ref> To create the map, Unite for Literacy performed a statistical analyses of data from the National Assessment of Educational Progress and the American Community Survey. Data used in the map includes the number of books in 4th graders' homes, average community income, ethnic diversity, geographic location and home language. Unite for Literacy unveiled the map during the [[Clinton Global Initiative]] America (CGI America) meeting held in Denver, Colorado, in June 2014.

In [[mathematics]], especially [[vector calculus]] and [[differential topology]], a '''closed form''' is a [[differential form]] ''α'' whose [[exterior derivative]] is zero ({{nowrap|1=''dα'' = 0}}), and an '''exact form''' is a differential form, ''α'', that is the exterior derivative of another differential form ''β''. Thus, an ''exact'' form is in the ''[[image (mathematics)|image]]'' of ''d'', and a ''closed'' form is in the ''[[kernel (algebra)|kernel]]'' of ''d''.
For an exact form ''α'', {{nowrap|1=''α'' = ''dβ''}} for some differential form ''β'' of degree one less than that of ''α''. The form ''β'' is called a "potential form" or "primitive" for ''α''. Since the exterior derivative of a closed form is zero, ''β'' is not unique, but can be modified by the addition of any closed form of degree one less than that of ''α''.
Because {{nowrap|1=''d''{{i sup|2}} = 0}}, any exact form is necessarily closed. The question of whether ''every'' closed form is exact depends on the [[topology]] of the domain of interest. On a [[Contractible space|contractible]] domain, every closed form is exact by the [[#Poincaré lemma|Poincaré lemma]]. More general questions of this kind on an arbitrary [[differentiable manifold]] are the subject of [[de Rham cohomology]], which allows one to obtain purely [[algebraic topology|topological]] information using differential methods.
== Examples == {{details|Winding number}} [[File:Irrotationalfield.svg|thumb|Vector field corresponding to ''dθ''.]] A simple example of a form which is closed but not exact is the 1-form <math>d\theta</math><ref group=note>This is an abuse of notation. The argument <math>\theta</math> is not a well-defined function, and <math>d\theta</math> is not the differential of any zero-form. The discussion that follows elaborates on this.</ref> given by the derivative of [[Argument (complex analysis)|argument]] on the [[punctured plane]] <math>\mathbf{R}^2\setminus\{0\}</math>. Since <math>\theta</math> is not actually a function (see the next paragraph) <math>d\theta</math> is not an exact form. Still, <math>d\theta</math> has vanishing derivative and is therefore closed.
Note that the argument <math>\theta</math> is only defined up to an integer multiple of <math>2\pi</math> since a single point <math>p</math> can be assigned different arguments <math>r</math>, <math>r+2\pi</math>, etc. We can assign arguments in a locally consistent manner around <math>p</math>, but not in a globally consistent manner. This is because if we trace a loop from <math>p</math> counterclockwise around the origin and back to <math>p</math>, the argument increases by <math>2\pi</math>. Generally, the argument <math>\theta</math> changes by :<math>\oint_{S^1} d\theta</math> over a counter-clockwise oriented loop <math>S^1</math>.
Even though the argument <math>\theta</math> is not technically a function, the different ''local'' definitions of <math>\theta</math> at a point <math>p</math> differ from one another by constants. Since the derivative at <math>p</math> only uses local data, and since functions that differ by a constant have the same derivative, the argument has a globally well-defined derivative "<math>d\theta</math>".<ref group=note>The article [[covering space|covering spaces]] has more information on the mathematics of functions that are only locally well-defined.</ref>
The upshot is that <math>d\theta</math> is a one-form on <math>\mathbf{R}^2\setminus\{0\}</math> that is not actually the derivative of any well-defined function <math>\theta</math>. We say that <math>d\theta</math> is not ''exact''. Explicitly, <math>d\theta</math> is given as: :<math>d\theta = \frac{-y\,dx + x\,dy}{x^2+y^2}</math>, which by inspection has derivative zero. Because <math>d\theta</math> has vanishing derivative, we say that it is ''closed''.
This form generates the de Rham cohomology group <math>H^1_{dR}(\mathbf{R}^2\setminus\{0\}) \cong \mathbf{R},</math> meaning that any closed form <math>\omega</math> is the sum of an exact form <math>df</math> and a multiple of <math>d\theta:</math> <math>\omega = df + k\ d\theta,</math> where <math>\textstyle{k = \frac{1}{2\pi}\oint_{S^1} \omega}</math> accounts for a non-trivial contour integral around the origin, which is the only obstruction to a closed form on the punctured plane (locally the derivative of a [[function (mathematics)|potential function]]) being the derivative of a globally defined function.
==Examples in low dimensions==
Differential forms in '''R'''<sup>2</sup> and '''R'''<sup>3</sup> were well known in the [[mathematical physics]] of the nineteenth century. In the plane, 0-forms are just functions, and 2-forms are functions times the basic area element {{nowrap|''dx'' ∧ ''dy''}}, so that it is the 1-forms
:<math> \alpha = f(x,y) \, dx + g(x,y) \, dy</math>
that are of real interest. The formula for the [[exterior derivative]] ''d'' here is
:<math> d \alpha = (g_x-f_y) \, dx\wedge dy</math>
where the subscripts denote [[partial derivative]]s. Therefore the condition for <math>\alpha</math> to be ''closed'' is
:<math> f_y=g_x.</math>
In this case if {{nowrap|''h''(''x'', ''y'')}} is a function then
:<math> dh = h_x \, dx + h_y \, dy.</math>
The implication from 'exact' to 'closed' is then a consequence of the [[symmetry of second derivatives]], with respect to ''x'' and ''y''.
The [[gradient theorem]] asserts that a 1-form is exact if and only if the line integral of the form depends only on the endpoints of the curve, or equivalently, if the integral around any smooth closed curve is zero.
===Vector field analogies=== On a [[Riemannian manifold]], or more generally a [[pseudo-Riemannian manifold]], ''k''-forms correspond to ''k''-vector fields (by [[musical isomorphism | duality via the metric]]), so there is a notion of a vector field corresponding to a closed or exact form.
In 3 dimensions, an exact vector field (thought of as a 1-form) is called a [[conservative vector field]], meaning that it is the derivative ([[gradient]]) of a 0-form (smooth scalar field), called the [[scalar potential]]. A closed vector field (thought of as a 1-form) is one whose derivative ([[curl (mathematics)|curl]]) vanishes, and is called an [[irrotational vector field]].
Thinking of a vector field as a 2-form instead, a closed vector field is one whose derivative ([[divergence]]) vanishes, and is called an [[incompressible flow]] (sometimes [[solenoidal vector field]]).
The concepts of conservative and incompressible vector fields generalize to ''n'' dimensions, because gradient and divergence generalize to ''n'' dimensions; curl is defined only in three dimensions, thus the concept of irrotational vector field does not generalize in this way.
==Poincaré lemma<!--'Poincaré lemma' redirects here-->== The '''Poincaré lemma'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA--> states that if ''B'' is an open ball in '''R'''<sup>''n''</sup>, any smooth closed ''p''-form ''ω'' defined on ''B'' is exact, for any integer ''p'' with {{nowrap|1 ≤ ''p'' ≤ ''n''}}.<ref>{{harvnb|Warner|1983|pages=155-156}}</ref>
Translating if necessary, it can be assumed that the ball ''B'' has centre 0. Let ''α''<sub>''s''</sub> be the flow on '''R'''<sup>''n''</sup> defined by {{nowrap|1=''α''<sub>''s''</sub> '''x''' = ''e''<sup>−''s''</sup> '''x'''}}. For {{nowrap|''s'' ≥ 0}} it carries ''B'' into itself and induces an action on functions and differential forms. The derivative of the flow is the vector field ''X'' defined on functions ''f'' by {{nowrap|1=''Xf'' = ''d''(''α''<sub>''s''</sub>''f'')/''ds''|<sub>''s'' = 0</sub>}}: it is the ''radial vector field'' {{nowrap|1=−''r'' {{sfrac|∂|∂''r''}} = −∑ ''x''<sub>''i''</sub> {{sfrac|∂|∂''x''<sub>''i''</sub>}}}}. The derivative of the flow on forms defines the [[Lie derivative]] with respect to ''X'' given by {{nowrap|1=''L''<sub>''X''</sub> ''ω'' = ''d''(''α''<sub>''s''</sub>''ω'') /''ds''|<sub>''s''=0</sub>}}. In particular
:<math>\displaystyle{{d\over ds} \alpha_s \omega =\alpha_s L_X \omega,}</math>
Now define
:<math>\displaystyle{h\omega =-\int_0^\infty \alpha_t\omega \, dt.}</math>
By the [[fundamental theorem of calculus]] we have that
:<math>\displaystyle{hL_X\omega=-\int_0^\infty \alpha_t L_X \omega \, dt=-\int_0^\infty {d\over dt} (\alpha_t \omega) \, dt= -[\alpha _t \omega]_0^\infty= \omega.}</math>
With <math>\displaystyle{\iota_X}</math> being the [[interior multiplication]] or contraction by the vector field ''X'', Cartan's formula writes:
:<math>\displaystyle{L_X = d\iota_X + \iota_X d.}</math>
Using the fact that ''d'' commutes with ''h'' (as ''α''<sub>''s''</sub> does with ''d'') we get:
:<math>\displaystyle{ hL_X\omega = h (d\iota_X + \iota_X d) \omega = d (h\iota_X \omega) + h \iota_X d \omega =\omega} </math>.
It now follows that if ''ω'' is closed, i. e. {{nowrap|1=''dω'' = 0}}, then {{nowrap|1=''d''(''h'' ''ι''<sub>''X''</sub>''ω'') = ''ω''}}, so that ''ω'' is exact and the Poincaré lemma is proved.
(In the language of [[homological algebra]], {{nowrap|''h'' ∘ ''ι''<sub>''X''</sub>}} is a "contracting homotopy".)
The same method applies to any open set in '''R'''<sup>''n''</sup> that is star-shaped about 0, i.e. any open set containing 0 and invariant under ''α''<sub>''t''</sub> for <math>\displaystyle{1 < t < \infty}</math>.
'''Example''': In two dimensions the Poincaré lemma can be proved directly for closed 1-forms and 2-forms as follows.<ref>{{harvnb|Napier|Ramachandran|2011|pages=443-444}}</ref>
If {{nowrap|1=''ω'' = ''p'' ''dx'' + ''q'' ''dy''}} is a closed 1-form on {{nowrap|(''a'', ''b'') × (''c'', ''d'')}}, then {{nowrap|1=''p''<sub>''y''</sub> = ''q''<sub>''x''</sub>}}. If {{nowrap|1=''ω'' = ''df''}} then {{nowrap|1=''p'' = ''f''<sub>''x''</sub>}} and {{nowrap|1=''q'' = ''f''<sub>''y''</sub>}}. Set
:<math>\displaystyle{g(x,y)=\int_a^x p(t,y)\, dt,}</math>
so that {{nowrap|1=''g''<sub>''x''</sub> = ''p''}}. Then {{nowrap|1=''h'' = ''f'' − ''g''}} must satisfy {{nowrap|1=''h''<sub>''x''</sub> = 0}} and {{nowrap|1=''h''<sub>''y''</sub> = ''q'' − ''g''<sub>''y''</sub>}}. The right hand side here is independent of ''x'' since its partial derivative with respect to ''x'' is 0. So
:<math>\displaystyle{h(x,y)=\int_c^y q(a,s)\, ds - g(a,y)=\int_c^y q(a,s)\, ds,}</math>
and hence
:<math>\displaystyle{f(x,y)=\int_a^x p(t,y)\, dt + \int_c^y q(a,s)\, ds.}</math>
Similarly, if {{nowrap|1=Ω = ''r'' ''dx'' ∧ ''dy''}} then {{nowrap|1=Ω = ''d''(''a'' ''dx'' + ''b'' ''dy'')}} with {{nowrap|1=''b''<sub>''x''</sub> − ''a''<sub>''y''</sub> = ''r''}}. Thus a solution is given by {{nowrap|1=''a'' = 0}} and
:<math>\displaystyle{b(x,y)=\int_a^x r(t,y) \, dt.}</math>
==Formulation as cohomology==
When the difference of two closed forms is an exact form, they are said to be '''cohomologous''' to each other. That is, if ''ζ'' and ''η'' are closed forms, and one can find some ''β'' such that
:<math>\zeta - \eta = d\beta</math>
then one says that ''ζ'' and ''η'' are cohomologous to each other. Exact forms are sometimes said to be '''cohomologous to zero'''. The set of all forms cohomologous to a given form (and thus to each other) is called a [[de Rham cohomology]] class; the general study of such classes is known as [[cohomology]]. It makes no real sense to ask whether a 0-form (smooth function) is exact, since ''d'' increases degree by 1; but the clues from topology suggest that only the zero function should be called "exact". The cohomology classes are identified with [[locally constant]] functions.
Using contracting homotopies similar to the one used in the proof of the Poincaré lemma, it can be shown that de Rham cohomology is homotopy-invariant. In general, non-contractible differentiable manifolds have non-trivial de Rham cohomology. For instance, on the circle ''S''<sup>1</sup>, parametrized by ''t'' in {{nowrap|[0, 1]}}, the closed 1-form ''dt'' is not exact.
==Application in electrodynamics==
In electrodynamics, the case of the magnetic field <math>\vec B(\mathbf r)</math> produced by a stationary electrical current is important. There one deals with the [[vector potential]] <math>\vec A(\mathbf r )</math> of this field. This case corresponds to {{nowrap|1=''k'' = 2}}, and the defining region is the full <math>\mathbb R^3\,.</math> The current-density vector is <math>\vec j\,.</math> It corresponds to the current two-form
:<math>\mathbf I :=j_1(x_1,x_2, x_3) \, {\rm d}x_2\wedge {\rm d}x_3+j_2(x_1,x_2, x_3) \, {\rm d}x_3\wedge {\rm d}x_1+j_3(x_1,x_2, x_3) \, {\rm d}x_1\wedge {\rm d}x_2.</math>
For the magnetic field <math>\vec B</math> one has analogous results: it corresponds to the induction two-form <math>\Phi_B:=B_1{\rm d}x_2\wedge {\rm d}x_3 +\cdots ,</math> and can be derived from the vector potential <math>\vec A</math>, or the corresponding one-form <math>\mathbf A</math>,
:<math> \vec B ={\rm curl\,\,}\vec A =\left\{ \frac{\partial A_3}{\partial x_2}-\frac{\partial A_2}{\partial x_3} , \frac{\partial A_1}{\partial x_3}-\frac{\partial A_3}{\partial x_1} ,\frac{\partial A_2}{\partial x_1}-\frac{\partial A_1}{\partial x_2}\right\},\text{ or }\Phi_B={\rm d}\mathbf A.</math>
Thereby the vector potential <math>\vec A</math> corresponds to the potential one-form
:<math>\mathbf A:=A_1 \, {\rm d}x_1+A_2 \, {\rm d}x_2+A_3 \, {\rm d}x_3.</math>
The closedness of the magnetic-induction two-form corresponds to the property of the magnetic field that it is source-free:   <math> {\rm div\,\,}\vec B \equiv 0,</math> i.e. that there are no magnetic [[Magnetic monopole|monopole]]s.
In a special gauge, <math>\operatorname{div}\vec A{~\stackrel{!}{=}~}0</math>, this implies for ''i'' = 1, 2, 3
:<math>A_i(\vec r) =\int \frac{\mu_0 j_i(\vec r^{\,'})\,\, dx_1'dx_2'dx_3'}{4\pi |\vec r -\vec r^{\,'}|}\,.</math>
(Here <math>\mu_0</math> is a constant, the magnetic vacuum permeability.)
This equation is remarkable, because it corresponds completely to a well-known formula for the ''electrical'' field <math>\vec E</math>, namely for the ''electrostatic Coulomb potential'' <math>\,\phi (x_1,x_2, x_3)</math> of a ''charge density'' <math>\rho (x_1,x_2,x_3)</math>. At this place one can already guess that
*<math>\vec E</math> and <math>\vec B ,</math> *<math>\rho </math> and <math>\vec j ,</math> *<math>\,\phi</math> and <math>\vec A</math>
can be ''unified'' to quantities with six rsp. four nontrivial components, which is the basis of the [[relativistic invariance]] of the [[Maxwell equations]].
If the condition of stationarity is left, on the ''l.h.s.'' of the above-mentioned equation one must add, in the equations for <math>A_i\,,</math> to the three space coordinates, as a fourth variable also the time ''t'', whereas on the ''r.h.s.'', in <math>j_i' \,,</math> the so-called "retarded time",   <math>t':=t-\frac{|\vec r -\vec r^{\,'}|}{c}\,,</math> must be used, i.e. it is added to the argument of the current-density. Finally, as before, one integrates over the three primed space coordinates. (As usual ''c'' is the vacuum velocity of light.)

The field of '''conflict early warning''' seeks to forecast the outbreak of [[armed conflict]], or, at minimum, to detect the early escalation of violence, with the objective of preventing the outbreak or the further escalation of violence in order to save lives.<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Rupesinghe |editor1-first=Kumar |editor1-link=Kumar Rupesinghe |editor2-last=Kuroda |editor2-first=Michiko |date=1992 |title=Early warning and conflict resolution |location=New York |publisher=[[St. Martin's Press]] |isbn=0312085648 |oclc=25834272 |ref=harv}}</ref>
Initial conceptions of conflict early warning materialized in the 1970s and 1980s but the field really emerged on the international policy agenda after the end of the [[Cold War]].<ref name="Nyheim">{{cite conference |last=Nyheim |first=David |authorlink=David Nyheim |date=18 May 2008 |title=Can violence, war, and state collapse be prevented? The future of operational conflict early warning and response systems |book-title=10th meeting of the DAC Fragile States Group and Conflict, Peace and Development Co-operation |location=Paris |publisher=The DAC Network on Conflict, Peace and Development Co-Operation & The DAC Fragile States Group Joint Session |pages=7, 14 |url=http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.189.303&rep=rep1&type=pdf |ref=harv}}</ref> Both qualitative and quantitative approaches have been developed for conflict forecasting and conflict monitoring.<ref>{{cite book |last=Austin |first=Alexander |date=2004 |chapter=Early warning and the field: a cargo cult science? |editor1-last=Austin |editor1-first=Alex |editor2-last=Fischer |editor2-first=Martina |editor3-last=Ropers |editor3-first=Norbert |title=Transforming ethnopolitical conflict: the Berghof handbook |series=Berghof Forschungszentrum für Konstruktive Konfliktbearbeitung; Berghof Research Center for Constructive Conflict Management |location=Wiesbaden |publisher=VS Verlag für Sozialwissenschaften |isbn=3810039403 |oclc=57283507 |doi=10.1007/978-3-663-05642-3_7 |chapterurl=http://edoc.vifapol.de/opus/volltexte/2011/2575/pdf/austin_handbook.pdf |ref=harv}}</ref> Qualitative methodologies typically draw on local area experts with extensive knowledge on one country or region. This is the approach taken by the [[International Crisis Group]],<ref>{{cite web |last=Grono |first=Nick |date=11 November 2006 |title=The challenge of anticipating conflict |url=http://www.crisisgroup.org/en/publication-type/speeches/2006/the-challenge-of-anticipating-conflict.aspx |website=crisisgroup.org |publisher=[[International Crisis Group]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100808235619/http://www.crisisgroup.org/en/publication-type/speeches/2006/the-challenge-of-anticipating-conflict.aspx |archivedate=2010-08-08 |accessdate=2016-04-19}}</ref> for example. In contrast, quantitative methodologies quantify conflict trends and use mathematical techniques to forecast future trends or "events of interest" (EOIs) such as the onset of conflicts.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Chadefaux |first=Thomas |date=January 2014 |title=Early warning signals for war in the news |journal=[[Journal of Peace Research]] |volume=51 |issue=1 |pages=5–18 |doi=10.1177/0022343313507302 |url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Thomas_Chadefaux/publication/256044330_Early_Warning_Signals_for_War_in_the_News/links/0c96052a992664d50d000000.pdf |ref=harv}}</ref> For example, the [[Integrated Conflict Early Warning System]] (ICEWS) project at the [[Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency]] (DARPA) takes this approach.<ref>{{cite journal |last=O'Brien |first=Sean P. |date=March 2010 |title=Crisis early warning and decision support: contemporary approaches and thoughts on future research |journal=[[International Studies Review]] |volume=12 |issue=1 |pages=87–104 |doi=10.1111/j.1468-2486.2009.00914.x |ref=harv}}</ref> Some approaches to conflict early warning combine both qualitative and quantitative methodologies, such as [[Swisspeace]]'s formerly operational project called FAST.<ref name="FAST">{{cite book |last=Krummenacher |first=Heinz |date=2006 |chapter=Computer assisted early warning—the FAST example |editor-last=Trappl |editor-first=Robert |editor-link=Robert Trappl |title=Programming for peace: computer-aided methods for international conflict resolution and prevention |series=Advances in group decision and negotiation |volume=2 |location=Dordrecht |publisher=[[Springer Verlag]] |pages=71–80 |isbn=1402043775 |oclc=63764074 |doi=10.1007/1-4020-4390-2_4 |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=o6Fv7XFhQgMC&pg=PA71 |ref=harv}}</ref>
==Origins== The unanticipated events of the [[Yom Kippur War]] in 1973 and that of the [[Falklands War]] in 1982 provoked a series of debates over the lack of early warning. The incident over the Falklands had taken the [[United Nations]] completely by surprise and it is said "no map of the islands was available in the Secretariat when the invasion began".<ref>{{cite book |last=Peck |first=Connie |date=1998 |title=Sustainable peace: the role of the UN and regional organizations in preventing conflict |series=Carnegie Commission on Preventing Deadly Conflict series |location=Lanham, MD |publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]] |isbn=0847685608 |oclc=37180967 |page=[//books.google.com/books?id=zycKkwkkzNAC&pg=PA72 72] |ref=harv}}</ref> The initial drivers, however, were humanitarian agencies "driven by the need for accurate and timely predictions of refugee flows to enable effective contingency planning".<ref name="Nyheim"/> After the end of the Cold War, political scientists at leading academic institutions began modifying old Cold War models of conflict to understand the onset of new wars. The horrors of the 1994 [[Rwandan genocide]] also spurred increased interest in operational conflict early warning systems. The FAST project of Swisspeace<ref name="FAST"/> and the [[Forum on Early Warning and Early Response]] (FEWER) were responses to the [[genocide]].

==Further reading== * {{cite book |last=Alker |first=Hayward R. |authorlink=Hayward Alker |date=2005 |chapter=Designing information resources for transboundary conflict early warning networks |editor1-last=Latham |editor1-first=Robert |editor2-last=Sassen |editor2-first=Saskia |editor2-link=Saskia Sassen |title=Digital formations: IT and new architectures in the global realm |location=Princeton, NJ |publisher=[[Princeton University Press]] |pages=215–241 |isbn=0691119864 |oclc=57069068 |chapterurl=https://books.google.com/books?id=EfJFgAPK9ccC&pg=PA215 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |editor1-last=Alker |editor1-first=Hayward R. |editor1-link=Hayward Alker |editor2-last=Gurr |editor2-first=Ted Robert |editor2-link=Ted Robert Gurr |editor3-last=Rupesinghe |editor3-first=Kumar |editor3-link=Kumar Rupesinghe |date=2001 |title=Journeys through conflict: narratives and lessons |location=Lanham, MD |publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]] |isbn=0742510271 |oclc=46777394 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=I0soGy_LehMC |ref=harv}} * {{cite web |last=Brahm |first=Eric |date=January 2005 |title=Early warning |url=http://www.beyondintractability.org/essay/early-warning |website=beyondintractability.org |accessdate=2016-04-19 |ref=harv}} * {{cite book |editor1-last=Davies |editor1-first=John L. |editor2-last=Gurr |editor2-first=Ted Robert |editor2-link=Ted Robert Gurr |date=1998 |title=Preventive measures: building risk assessment and crisis early warning systems |location=Lanham, MD |publisher=[[Rowman & Littlefield]] |isbn=0847688739 |oclc=39627445 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=maWR6_GLMH4C |ref=harv}}
